topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Lenny introduces Christine Itwaru and frames the episode around understanding product ops: what it is, why it’s emerging, and how it helps product teams and leaders.

topics.title: Ben Williams story and giving back
topics.summary: Christine shares how an early conversation with Ben Williams validated that many teams share the same product-ops-type problems, motivating her to contribute back to the product community.

topics.title: Defining product ops vs product management
topics.summary: Christine defines product ops in two ways: as a system/process that helps product teams thrive, and as dedicated people who partner with PMs and advise product leadership using qualitative and quantitative insights.

topics.title: Why product ops emerged (the 2019 inflection)
topics.summary: They discuss why product ops felt like it “took off” around 2019: recurring product pains became more visible, and companies sought help operationalizing product decision-making and cross-functional alignment.

topics.title: Drivers: VoC, alignment, PLG, rapid growth
topics.summary: Christine explains the forces that increased demand for product ops: voice-of-customer synthesis, stakeholder transparency, pandemic-era growth, and the shift toward product-led growth requiring calmer, scalable systems.

topics.title: Core responsibilities: VoC, tooling, content, process
topics.summary: Christine outlines common product ops work: synthesizing qualitative/quantitative feedback, managing/optimizing the PM tool stack, embedding education/content into delivery, and (sometimes) improving planning/process in less mature orgs.

topics.title: How Pendo runs voice of customer
topics.summary: Christine describes Pendo’s VoC approach: bringing sales, success, and other teams together to align on themes, educate stakeholders, and distinguish between product changes vs enablement/documentation needs.

topics.title: Product ops relationship with user research
topics.summary: They clarify how product ops partners with UX research: research drives proactive validation and testing, while product ops aggregates inputs (e.g., NPS themes, revenue feedback) and collaborates with research to interpret and act on signals.

topics.title: Tooling and content strategy in practice
topics.summary: Christine distinguishes PM planning tools from the broader PM tool stack (Salesforce, Looker, integrations) and explains how product ops supports in-app education and documentation as part of “definition of done,” especially for PLG.

topics.title: Is product ops only for B2B?
topics.summary: Christine argues product ops isn’t limited to B2B; large B2C companies also face heavy cross-functional complexity. The common thread is transparency, readiness, and coordinated communication to internal teams and customers.

topics.title: Getting buy-in and avoiding PM resistance
topics.summary: They discuss how to position product ops so PMs don’t feel displaced: clarify PM accountability, secure leadership sponsorship, and emphasize freeing PM time from revenue-team firefighting to focus on customers and outcomes.

topics.title: What PMs should never offload
topics.summary: Christine insists the core PM responsibility is direct customer understanding—observing pain and building empathy. If a PM doesn’t want that, she argues they shouldn’t be in product.

topics.title: Product ops vs program management and agile roles
topics.summary: They compare adjacent roles and note that early product ops hires often get pulled into planning/process standardization. Christine differentiates product ops by deep product/customer/business understanding beyond facilitation.

topics.title: Are ops roles a sign of inefficiency?
topics.summary: Responding to a ‘spicy’ take, Christine argues ops roles often signal growth and complexity, not inefficiency. She agrees product ops should build systems, automate/hand off repeatable work, and evolve toward strategic advisory impact.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Ad read for Vanta, focusing on SOC 2 compliance automation and a listener discount.

topics.title: Signs you need product ops: transparency and readiness
topics.summary: Christine highlights indicators a product org needs product ops: poor transparency, misalignment with revenue teams, and weak launch readiness. She shares Pendo’s origin story—one bad launch exposed gaps and drove building a repeatable system.

topics.title: Measuring impact: inbound quality and surveys
topics.summary: Christine discusses early measurement approaches for product ops, including surveying PMs and revenue teams on time spent and question quality, then using that data to improve transparency mechanisms like a product digest.
